trans-unit.source: Before you can use Azure PowerShell, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Azure PowerShell, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Before you can use Windows PowerShell, you must have Windows PowerShell, Version 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Windows PowerShell, you must have Windows PowerShell, Version 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type this command at a Windows PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type this command at a Windows PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: You should see something like this.
trans-unit.target: You should see something like this.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the value of PSVersion is 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the value of PSVersion is 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: To install a compatible version, see <linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To install a compatible version, see <linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You should also have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: You should also have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: You should see something like this.
trans-unit.target: You should see something like this.

trans-unit.source: For instructions and a link to the latest version, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions and a link to the latest version, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> or sign up for a <linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> or sign up for a <linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt and log on to Azure with this command.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt and log on to Azure with this command.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can list your Azure subscriptions with this command.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can list your Azure subscriptions with this command.

trans-unit.source: You will receive the following type of information:
trans-unit.target: You will receive the following type of information:

trans-unit.source: You can set the current Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct name.
trans-unit.target: You can set the current Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct name.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure subscriptions and accounts, see <linkText>How to: Connect to your subscription</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure subscriptions and accounts, see <linkText>How to: Connect to your subscription</linkText><title></title>.
